gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
Module name: ex4_top.
Explanation: This module appears to convert a binary input to a BCD (Binary Coded Decimal) representation segmented onto four different BCD values, each representing a single digit of the overall decimal value; the BCD values are then converted to a 7-segment hexadecimal representation for display. The output for each 7-segment display is stored in HEX0, HEX1, HEX2, and HEX3 respectively. The binary input is fetched from a 10-bit switch (SW). Thus, the module is designed for 10-bit binary to 4-digit hexadecimal display conversion.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
Input ports: [SW]. Explanation: [SW is a 10-bit input bus. This contains the binary value that needs to be converted into a BCD, and then into a hexadecimal representation for display.]

Output ports: [HEX0, HEX1, HEX2, HEX3]. Explanation: [These are 7-bit output buses. Each contains the 7-segment hexadecimal representation of a single digit from the converted BCD. HEX0 outputs the least significant digit, and HEX3 outputs the most significant digit of the BCD representation.]

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
Internal signals: [BCD_0, BCD_1, BCD_2, BCD_3]. Explanation: [These are 4-bit internal buses. These carry the Binary Coded Decimal (BCD) representation after converting the binary input from the switch (SW). Each BCD signal represents one decimal digit. BCD_0 has the least significant decimal digit, and BCD_3 has the most significant decimal digit.]
